pullRequest.body:
This shows that regular languages are closed under complement and intersection by constructing DFAs for them.

---

Closure under all other operations will be proved when someone adds the proof for DFA<->regular expression equivalence, so they are not part of this PR.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

please_merge_master.md
please_merge_master.md
please_merge_master.md

@EtienneC30 Adding set notation for the closure properties requires adding `Union` and `Intersection` instances to `Language`, which is not defined in this module (it is defined in `Computability/Language`). Should I add them as part of this PR or create a new PR?

You can add them in this PR it's fine. The union of languages is actually already defined there but it is registered with an `Add` instance, so the notation is `+`. There is nothing for the intersection, I don't know if there is a special convention for the intersection of languages which uses something other than `∩`, but I guess if it was not registered it's not the case, so you can go with `∩`.
Don't forget to remove the awaiting-author label when you are done.
please_merge_master.md
please_merge_master.md
please_merge_master.md

@EtienneC30 I added the `Inter` instance for `Language` and added the set notation-based proofs to `Computability/DFA`. I also removed explicit uses of `Set` methods in the closure proofs as you suggested. I am done with all changes.
Can you please merge master as suggested by the bot? I don't why it asks, maybe it's because the branch is a bit old, but I think it's better if you do it.

### PR summary [5fad7b37fc](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20238/commits/5fad7b37fcd1dc15bca7064e9f825be84cdfe167)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ compl`
`+ compl_accept_eq_accept_compl`
`+ compl_accept_iff`
`+ compl_accepts_eq_accepts_compl`
`+ compl_accepts_iff`
`+ instance : HasCompl (DFA α σ) := ⟨compl⟩`
`+ instance : Inter (Language α)`
`+ inter`
`+ inter_accept_eq_product_accept`
`+ inter_accept_iff`
`+ inter_accepts_iff`
`+ inter_accepts_inter`
`+ product`
`+ product_accept_iff`
`+ product_accepts_iff`
`+ product_evalFrom`
`+ union`
`+ union_accept_iff`
`+ union_accepts_iff`
`+ union_accepts_union`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
I renamed `intersect` to `inter` and replaced the `apply` with the term-mode proof.
This seems fine, just a few remarks about naming.
Thank you for this! Here are a few comments, also with suggestions for better readability.
This seems fine, just a few remarks about naming.
Maybe you can add the simp lemma which says `Mᶜ.accept = M.acceptᶜ` to be able to just write `simp`?

I don't exactly understand this suggestion.

Do you want to add another lemma like the following before this then just use `simp` here?

```lean
theorem compl_accept_eq_accept_compl (s : σ) : Mᶜ.accept = M.acceptᶜ := by ...
```
I added the lemma I mentioned above.
Yes that's what I meant!

```suggestion
 algebra operation `p`. `p` takes in whether `M₁` and `M₂` accept their respective inputs and
```
Do you think `product` would be ok as a name or might it conflict with something else? `cartesian_product` seems a bit lengthy.
changed the name to `product`

We prefer this syntax when instantiating structures. Same for `cartesian_product` below.
```suggestion
def compl (M : DFA α σ) : DFA α σ where
  step := M.step
  start := M.start
  accept := M.acceptᶜ
```

As the DFA is called compl maybe it's better to change the name of the lemma. Same below.
```suggestion
theorem compl_accept_iff (s : σ) : s ∈ Mᶜ.accept ↔ s ∉ M.accept := by
```
Changed it to `compl`.

The naming convention is to use `evalFrom` because it is one "block". You can check the naming conventions [here](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html) for more details.
```suggestion
theorem cartesian_product_evalFrom
```

We tend to avoid forall in statements. You can do `revert s` at the beginning of the proof to keep it working.
```suggestion
    (p : Prop → Prop → Prop) (M₁ : DFA α σ) (M₂ : DFA α σ') (x : List α) (s : σ × σ') :
    (cartesian_product p M₁ M₂).evalFrom s x = ⟨M₁.evalFrom s.1 x, M₂.evalFrom s.2 x⟩ := by
```
Thank you, I didn't know about the `revert` tactic. I changed the statement.
Can you use the `induction` tactic instead please? It improves readability.
I switched to `induction`. Does the result look like the preferred style in mathlib4?
Yes that's it, thanks!

You can merge the first two `simp`s together. Also, please avoid non terminal simp, i.e. a simp which does not finish the goal, as those are painful to repair when they break. Instead you can write `simp?` and apply the suggestion to turn into a `simp only`.
I think I applied your suggestion correctly, but I am not sure.

Yes that was what I meant. The use of `mem_setOf_eq` was bugging me because it's not something we usually write explicitly, and in fact you can just do this for the proof:
```lean
theorem product_accepts_iff
    (p : Prop → Prop → Prop) (M₁ : DFA α σ) (M₂ : DFA α σ') (x : List α) :
    x ∈ (M₁.product M₂ p).accepts ↔ p (x ∈ M₁.accepts) (x ∈ M₂.accepts) := by
  simp only [accepts, acceptsFrom, product_evalFrom]
  rfl
```
Thank you, I just changed the proof to this.

```suggestion
 There is no instance for this to provide the `M₁ ∩ M₂` syntax, because M₁ and M₂ have
```

You don't need the `DFA.` prefix as the namespace is open.
```suggestion
  dsimp [evalFrom, cartesian_product]
```
thanks, fixed this in other places too.

I've never used this part of the library. Do you think it might be useful to also state `Mᶜ.accepts = M.acceptsᶜ`? Same question for `(intersect M₁ M₂).accept = M₁.accept ×ˢ M₂.accept` and `(intersect M₁ M₂).accepts = M₁.accepts ∩ M₂.accepts`. These statements look natural to me.
This is also how the intersection theorem is stated in #22298. I think that is useful, and I will add those lemmas too.
Note that you can also write `M₁.intersect M₂` if you like.

You can also write `M₁.cartesian_product p M₂`. This feels a bit weird with the `p` in the middle, so you could move the p after the DFAs in the arguments of the def. This is just a suggestion, feel free to keep it as it is if you prefer.
That syntax is much clearer, thanks for the suggestion!

A proof which is just `by apply ...` can usually be replaced by a term-mode proof, which is nicer:
```suggestion
theorem compl_accepts_iff (x : List α) : x ∈ Mᶜ.accepts ↔ x ∉ M.accepts :=
  compl_accept_iff M _
```

I think this should be called `inter` because that's how we refer to intersection usually. You should also change the name of all the theorems which use `intersect`.
```suggestion
def inter (M₁ : DFA α σ) (M₂ : DFA α σ') : DFA α (σ × σ') := product M₁ M₂ And
```

The product of sets is referred to as `prod` in names.
```suggestion
theorem inter_accept_eq_prod_accept (M₁ : DFA α σ) (M₂ : DFA α σ') :
```

I would suggest this name:
```suggestion
theorem inter_accepts_eq_inter(M₁ : DFA α σ) (M₂ : DFA α σ') :
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Computability/DFA): Closure of regular languages under some set operations
